title: THIOTHIXENE - ORAL (Navane) side effects, medical uses, and drug interactions.
description: Consumer information about the medication THIOTHIXENE - ORAL (Navane), includes side effects, drug interactions, recommended dosages, and storage information. Read more about the prescription drug THIOTHIXENE - ORAL.
cleaned_text: and use of drug information on this site is subject to express terms of use. By continuing to view the drug information, you agree to abide by such terms of use. GENERIC NAME: THIOTHIXENE - | [Storage](#Storage) [WARNING: There may be a slightly increased risk of serious, possibly fatal side effects (such as ] [heart failure](https://www.medicinenet.com/heart_failure/article.htm), fast/irregular heartbeat, [pneumonia](https://www.medicinenet.com/pneumonia_facts/article.htm)) when this medication is used by older adults with [dementia](https://www.medicinenet.com/dementia/article.htm). This medication is not approved for the treatment of [dementia](https://www.medicinenet.com/dementia_symptoms_and_signs/symptoms.htm)-related behavior problems. Discuss the risks and benefits of this medication, as well as other effective and possibly safer treatments for [dementia](https://www.medicinenet.com/dementia_pictures_slideshow/article.htm)-related behavior problems, with the doctor. [USES: Thiothixene is used to treat certain mental/mood disorders (such as ] [schizophrenia](https://www.medicinenet.com/schizophrenia/article.htm)). This medicine helps you to think more clearly, feel less nervous, and take part in everyday life. It can reduce aggression and the desire to hurt yourself/others. It may also help to decrease [hallucinations](https://www.medicinenet.com/hallucinations/symptoms.htm) (such as [hearing](https://www.medicinenet.com/deafness/article.htm)/seeing things that are not there). Thiothixene is a psychiatric medication (antipsychotic-type) that works by helping to restore the balance of certain natural substances (such as [dopamine](https://www.medicinenet.com/dopamine-injection/article.htm)) in the brain. [HOW TO USE: Take this medication by mouth with or without food, usually 1-3 times daily or as directed by your doctor.Dosage is based on your age, medical condition, and response to treatment. To reduce your risk of side effects such as drowsiness and shaking (] [tremor](https://www.medicinenet.com/tremor/article.htm)), your doctor may direct you to start this medication at a low dose and gradually increase your dose. Follow your doctor's directions carefully.Take this medication regularly in order to get the most benefit from it. To help you remember, take it at the same time(s) each day.Although you may notice some medication effects soon after starting, for some conditions it may take 2 to 3 weeks before you get the full benefit of this drug.Do not stop taking this medication without consulting your doctor. Some conditions may become worse when this drug is suddenly stopped. Also, you may experience symptoms such as severe [confusion](https://www.medicinenet.com/confusion/symptoms.htm) and hallucinations. To prevent these symptoms while you are stopping treatment with this drug, your doctor may reduce your dose gradually. Consult your doctor or pharmacist for more details. Report any new or worsening symptoms immediately.Tell your doctor if your condition does not improve or if it worsens. [SIDE EFFECTS: vision](https://www.medicinenet.com/blurred_vision/symptoms.htm), [constipation](https://www.medicinenet.com/constipation/article.htm), and trouble sleeping may occur. If any of these effects persist or worsen, tell your doctor or pharmacist promptly.To reduce the risk of [dizziness](https://www.medicinenet.com/dizziness/symptoms.htm) and [lightheadedness](https://www.medicinenet.com/dizziness_dizzy/article.htm), get up slowly when rising from a sitting or lying position.This drug may cause muscle/nervous system problems (extrapyramidal symptoms-EPS). Your doctor may prescribe another medication to decrease these side effects. Therefore, tell your doctor immediately if you notice any of the following side effects: stiff muscles, severe [muscle spasms](https://www.medicinenet.com/muscle_spasms/article.htm)/cramping (such as twisting neck, arching back, eyes rolling up), restlessness/constant need to move, shaking ( [tremor](https://www.medicinenet.com/tremor/symptoms.htm)), slow/shuffling walk, [drooling](https://www.medicinenet.com/drooling/symptoms.htm)/trouble swallowing, mask-like expression of the face.Remember that your doctor has prescribed this medication because he or she has judged that the benefit to you is greater than the risk of side effects. Many people taking this medication do not have serious side effects.Tell your doctor immediately if any of these unlikely but serious side effects occur: [fainting](https://www.medicinenet.com/fainting/article.htm), confusion, [depression](https://www.medicinenet.com/depression/article.htm)/ [suicidal thoughts](https://www.medicinenet.com/suicide/article.htm), [difficulty a condition known as [tardive dyskinesia](https://www.medicinenet.com/tardive_dyskinesia/article.htm). In some cases, this condition may be permanent. Tell your doctor immediately if you develop any involuntary/repetitive muscle movements such as lip smacking/puckering, tongue thrusting, chewing, or finger/toe movements.In rare cases, thiothixene may increase your level of a certain chemical made by the body ( [prolactin](https://www.medicinenet.com/prolactinoma/article.htm)). For females, this increase in prolactin may result in unwanted [breast milk](https://www.medicinenet.com/breastfeeding/article.htm), missed/stopped periods, or difficulty [becoming pregnant](https://www.medicinenet.com/trying_to_conceive/article.htm). For males, it may result in decreased sexual ability, inability to produce sperm, or enlarged breasts. If you develop any of these symptoms, tell your doctor immediately.Tell your doctor immediately if any of these rare but very serious side effects occur: [easy bruising](https://www.medicinenet.com/bruises/article.htm)/bleeding, signs of infection severe stomach/ [abdominal pain](https://www.medicinenet.com/abdominal_pain_causes_remedies_treatment/article.htm), [seizures](https://www.medicinenet.com/seizures_symptoms_and_types/article.htm).This medication rarely cause a very serious condition called neuroleptic [malignant](https://www.medicinenet.com/cancer_101_pictures_slideshow/article.htm) syndrome (NMS). Get medical help right away if you have any of the following symptoms: [fever](https://www.medicinenet.com/fever/symptoms.htm), muscle [stiffness](https://www.medicinenet.com/joint_stiffness/symptoms.htm)/ in the amount of urine.A very serious [allergic reaction](https://www.medicinenet.com/allergies_quiz/quiz.htm) to this drug is rare. However, seek immediate medical attention if you notice any symptoms of a serious [allergic](https://www.medicinenet.com/allergy/article.htm) reaction, including: [rash](https://www.medicinenet.com/rash/article.htm), [itching](https://www.medicinenet.com/itch/article.htm)/swelling (especially of the face/tongue/throat), severe dizziness, trouble [breathing](https://www.medicinenet.com/lungs_design_and_purpose/article.htm).This is not a complete list of possible side effects. If you notice other effects not listed above, contact your doctor or pharmacist.In the US -Call your doctor for medical advice about side effects. You may report side effects to FDA at 1-800-FDA-1088.In Canada - Call your doctor for medical advice about side effects. You may report side effects to Health Canada at 1-866-234-2345. [PRECAUTIONS: See also Warning section.Before taking this medication, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to it; or if you have any other ] [allergies](https://www.medicinenet.com/allergy/article.htm). This product may contain inactive ingredients, which can cause allergic reactions or other problems. Talk to your pharmacist for more details.Before using this medication, tell your doctor or pharmacist your medical history, especially of: blood problems (such as low red/white/platelet blood cell counts), a certain eye condition ( [glaucoma](https://www.medicinenet.com/glaucoma/article.htm)), [heart](https://www.medicinenet.com/heart_how_the_heart_works/article.htm) problems other antipsychotic-type medications (neuroleptic malignant syndrome-NMS), slow movement of the gut/ [intestines](https://www.medicinenet.com/image-collection/intestines_picture/picture.htm) (such as chronic [constipation](https://www.medicinenet.com/constipation_myths_facts_pictures_slideshow/article.htm), intestinal blockage), difficulty urinating (such as due to prostate problems).This drug may make you dizzy or drowsy or cause blurred vision. Do not drive, use machinery, or do any activity that requires alertness or clear vision until you are sure you can perform such activities safely. Avoid alcoholic [beverages](https://www.medicinenet.com/drinks_and_beverages_quiz/quiz.htm).This medication may make you more sensitive to the sun. Avoid prolonged sun exposure, tanning booths, and sunlamps. Use a [sunscreen](https://www.medicinenet.com/sun_protection_and_sunscreens/article.htm) and wear protective clothing when outdoors.Before having surgery or imaging procedures (such as certain [X-rays](https://www.medicinenet.com/x-rays/article.htm), [CT scans](https://www.medicinenet.com/cat_scan/article.htm)) requiring the use of contrast dye (such as metrizamide), tell your doctor or dentist that you are using this medication and about all the products you use (including prescription [drugs](https://www.medicinenet.com/drugs_what_you_should_know_about_your_drugs/article.htm), nonprescription drugs, and herbal products).This medication may decrease your ability to sweat, making you more likely to get [heat stroke](https://www.medicinenet.com/heat_stroke/article.htm). Avoid activities that may cause you to overheat (such as doing strenuous work/ [exercise](https://www.medicinenet.com/exercise/article.htm) in hot weather, using hot tubs). When the weather is hot, drink plenty of fluids and dress lightly. If you become overheated, promptly seek cooler shelter and stop exercising. Seek immediate medical attention if you develop a fever, mental/ [mood changes](https://www.medicinenet.com/mood_swings/symptoms.htm), [headache](https://www.medicinenet.com/headache/article.htm), or dizziness.Older adults may be more sensitive to the side effects of this drug, especially dizziness (more likely when standing up), drowsiness, confusion, [constipation](https://www.medicinenet.com/constipation/symptoms.htm), trouble urinating, extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS), and [tardive](https://www.medicinenet.com/tardive_dyskinesia/article.htm) [dyskinesia](https://www.medicinenet.com/tardive_dyskinesia/article.htm) (TD) (see Side Effects). Dizziness, drowsiness, and confusion can increase the risk of falling.During [pregnancy](https://www.medicinenet.com/pregnancy_planning_preparing_for_pregnancy/article.htm), this medication should be used only when clearly needed. Discuss the risks and benefits with your doctor. Do not stop taking this medication unless directed by your doctor. [Babies](https://www.medicinenet.com/babies_quiz/quiz.htm) born to mothers who have used this drug during the last 3 months of pregnancy may infrequently develop symptoms including muscle stiffness or shakiness, drowsiness, feeding/breathing difficulties, or constant crying. If you notice any of these symptoms in your [newborn](https://www.medicinenet.com/babies_quiz/quiz.htm) anytime during their first month, tell the doctor right away.It is unknown if this medication passes into breast milk. Consult your doctor before breast-feeding. [](https://www.medicinenet.com/laughter_quiz/quiz.htm) QUESTIONSee Answer [DRUG INTERACTIONS](https://www.medicinenet.com/drug_interactions/article.htm): Drug interactions may change how your medications work or increase your risk for serious side effects. This document does not contain all possible drug interactions. Keep a list of all the products you use (including prescription/nonprescription drugs and herbal products) and share it with your doctor and pharmacist. Do not start, stop, or change the dosage of any medicines without your doctor's approval.Some products that may interact with this drug include: anticholinergic/antispasmodic drugs (such as [atropine](https://www.medicinenet.com/atropine-oral/article.htm), [dicyclomine](https://www.medicinenet.com/dicyclomine/article.htm), [scopolamine](https://www.medicinenet.com/scopolamine/article.htm)), [lithium](https://www.medicinenet.com/lithium/article.htm), drugs that increase the amount of dopamine in your body (such as [cabergoline](https://www.medicinenet.com/cabergoline-oral/article.htm), [pergolide](https://www.medicinenet.com/pergolide-oral/article.htm), [ropinirole](https://www.medicinenet.com/ropinirole-oral/article.htm)), drugs that lower [blood pressure](https://www.medicinenet.com/image-collection/blood_pressure_picture/picture.htm) (such as guanethidine, alpha blockers like [prazosin](https://www.medicinenet.com/prazosin-oral/article.htm)).Other medications can affect the removal of thiothixene from your body, which may affect how thiothixene works. One example is [carbamazepine](https://www.medicinenet.com/carbamazepine/article.htm). Other drugs not listed may also affect the removal.Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are taking other products that cause drowsiness including alcohol, [antihistamines](https://www.medicinenet.com/antihistamines-oral/article.htm) (such as [cetirizine](https://www.medicinenet.com/cetirizine/article.htm), [diphenhydramine](https://www.medicinenet.com/diphenhydramine/article.htm)), relievers (such as [codeine](https://www.medicinenet.com/codeine/article.htm)).Check the labels on all your medicines (such as [allergy](https://www.medicinenet.com/allergy/article.htm) or [cough](https://www.medicinenet.com/chronic_cough/article.htm)-and- [cold](https://www.medicinenet.com/common_cold/article.htm) products) because they may contain ingredients that cause drowsiness. Ask your pharmacist about using those products safely.Also tell your doctor if you take any drugs that might increase your risk of a [seizure](https://www.medicinenet.com/seizure/article.htm) when combined with thiothixene, such as your doctor or pharmacist for details. [OVERDOSE: If overdose is suspected, contact a ] [poison control](https://www.medicinenet.com/poison_control_centers/article.htm) center or emergency room immediately. US residents can call their local poison control center at 1-800-222-1222. Canada residents can call a provincial poison control center. Symptoms of overdose may include: severe drowsiness/dizziness, inability to wake up ( [coma](https://www.medicinenet.com/coma/article.htm)). [NOTES: Do not share this medication with others.Laboratory and/or medical tests (such as ] [complete blood count](https://www.medicinenet.com/complete_blood_count/article.htm), eye exams) should be performed periodically to monitor your progress or check for side effects. Consult your doctor for more details. [MISSED DOSE: If you miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember. If it is near the time of the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your usual dosing schedule. Do not double the dose to catch up.] [STORAGE: Store the American product at room temperature between 68-77 degrees F (20-25 degrees C) away from light and moisture. Do not store in the bathroom.Store the Canadian product between 59-86 degrees F (15-30 degrees C) away from light and moisture. Do not store in the bathroom.Keep all medicines away from children and pets.Do not ] [flush](https://www.medicinenet.com/hot_flashes/article.htm) medications down the toilet or pour them into a drain unless instructed to do so. Properly discard this product when it is expired or no longer needed. Consult your pharmacist or local waste disposal company for more details about how to safely discard your product. Information last revised December 2013. Copyright(c) 2013 First Databank, Inc. Related Disease Conditions - Brief Psychotic Disorder Brief psychotic disorder is a short-term mental illness that features psychotic symptoms. There are three forms of brief psychotic disorder. The first occurs shortly after a major stress, the second has no apparent trauma that triggers the illness, and the third is associated with postpartum onset. Symptoms include hallucinations, delusions, unusual behavior, disorientation, changes in eating and sleeping, and speech that doesn't make sense. Treatment typically involves medication and psychotherapy. Treatment & Diagnosis [Poor Doctor's Appointment](https://www.medicinenet.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=50586) [Schizotypal Personality Disorder](https://www.medicinenet.com/schizotypal_personality_disorder_symptoms_and_sign/symptoms.htm) Medications & Supplements Prevention & Wellness Report Problems to the Food and Drug Administration You are encouraged to report negative side effects of prescription drugs to the FDA. Visit the [FDA MedWatch](http://www.fda.gov/medwatch/report/consumer/consumer.htm) website or call 1-800-FDA-1088.
